index.content:
זְכֹר יְמוֹת עוֹלָם, בִּינוּ שְׁנוֹת דֹּר וָדֹר;    
שְׁאַל אָבִיךָ וְיַגֵּדְךָ, זְקֵנֶיךָ וְיֹאמְרוּ לָךְ.    

(דברים ל״ב, ז)


"Remember the days of old,
consider the years of many generations;
ask your father, and he will tell you,
your elders, and they will explain to you."


(Deuteronomy 32:7)

pages/about.title: about
pages/about.content:
The information on this website is based on material that my father, Peter Hoffman, collected, researched, and compiled over many years. When uploading the information to this website, I made every effort to remain faithful to the source.
If there is an error in the information or if a piece of information is missing, please feel free to contact me at moshe.hoffman@gmail.com.
Contributing
Family members who are interested in contributing are warmly welcomed! If you would like to:

Add biographies or stories about relatives
Share photographs or documents
Write a few words about family members
Provide corrections or additional information

Please contact me at moshe.hoffman@gmail.com, and I will be happy to help you add your contributions to the site.
Acknowledgments
This project would not be possible without the dedication of family members who have shared their stories, preserved precious documents, and supported the effort to document our collective history.

pages/founders.title: founders
pages/founders.content:
The Founding Generation
Savran: The Ancestral Home
Our family’s story begins in Savran (סברן), a small town on the banks of the Lower Bug River in the Podolia Governate of the Russian Empire, in what is now the Odessa Oblast, Ukraine.

Until the late 18th century, Podolia formed part of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth and had a sizable Jewish population, numbering in the tens of thousands. In the Second Partition of Poland (1793), most of Podolia was incorporated into the Russian Empire. Under the new regime, Jews were largely confined to the former Polish territories that became known as the Pale of Jewish Settlement, and they were subjected to an extensive body of discriminatory legislation.
By the 1880s, Savran had a substantial Jewish community. Archival tax records from the early 1880s indicate roughly one thousand Jewish households in the town. In 1900, even after many families had emigrated, the Jewish population still numbered 3,198 persons, making up a significant share of Savran’s inhabitants.
Many of the shtetls of Podolia were important centers of Hasidic Judaism, including Bratslav, Uman, Tulchin, and Mezhibozh. Jewish life revolved around the synagogue, the heder (religious elementary school), and dense networks of mutual aid and family ties. Most Jews earned their livelihood as merchants, craftsmen, or small-scale traders, and were generally barred by law from owning agricultural land.
The majority Ukrainian population, influenced by centuries of church teachings, harbored deep antisemitism. As one family member later recalled: “The Ukrainians imbibe their antisemitism with their mothers’ milk”—a Yiddish saying he had learned from his parents.
Wolf and Beile: The Founders
Wolf זאב Hochman (circa 1840–circa 1890) was a timber merchant and cartwright in Savran. The surname Hochman is Yiddish for “tall man.” Little else is known about Wolf’s life, but he must have been a man of some means to support a large family in those difficult times.
Wolf’s wife was Beile ביילא Hochman (née Alzofen). The name Beile is derived from the Slavic word “biela,” meaning “white.” Outside Russia, her name was often recorded as “Bella”.
Her maiden name, Alzofen (or Elizafan), is particularly rare and significant. It derives from Elitzafan ben Uziel (אליצפן בן עוזיאל), a Levite and cousin of Aaron and Moses who, according to the Torah (Exodus 6:22), took Aaron’s sons Nadav and Avihu for burial. This distinguished biblical name appears in only a handful of Jewish families from the Russian Empire.
Wolf died between 1890 and 1892, when his youngest children were still small. We know this from Ashkenazi naming customs: sons are named after deceased ancestors, and in November 1892, a grandson received the name Wolf. His grave is presumed to be in Savran’s Jewish cemetery, one of the few remnants of Jewish life that survived.
Beile outlived her husband by more than two decades. After seeing many of her children emigrate, she herself traveled to Ottoman Palestine around 1910. She passed away around 1914 or 1915 and was buried on the Mount of Olives in Jerusalem (הר הזיתים). We know this from family tradition and because a granddaughter born in Perth in 1915 was named Bella in her honor.
The family in Russia
Wolf זאב & Beile 
ביילא Hochman (Savran)
│
├─ Shimon Meir שמעון מאיר 
│   ├─ Berl 
│   └─ Hershl 
├─ Haim Yudl חיים יהודה 
├─ Avraham אברהם
├─ Yosef יוסף 
│   └─ Wolf 
├─ Kolman קלמן 
├─ Binyamin בנימין 
├─ Sholem שלום
├─ Moshe משה
├─ "Bobka" 
└─ Yisrael ישראל

The Children: A Generation Scattered
Wolf and Beile raised ten children in Savran during a time of increasing persecution and violence against Jews:
1. Shimon Meir מאיר Hochman (b. circa 1865)
The eldest son. Shimon and his young family left Savran for Palestine around 1890, fleeing pogroms with his infant son. He settled in Sarafand al-‘Amar (later Tzrifin) and worked in Baron Rothschild’s winery in Rishon LeZion. After his first wife Bracha died en route or shortly after arrival, he remarried Frieda Sisselman, daughter of a prominent rabbi in Jaffa.
Destination: Palestine
Read Shimon Meir’s full biography →
2. Haim Yehuda חיים יהודה Hochman (b. circa 1870)
The second son, known as Hyam Yudl. In his youth, he witnessed terrible pogroms in Savran. He married Sarah Bersharda in Balta on 15 August 1891. A member of the Hovevei Zion (Lovers of Zion) movement, Hyam purchased land in Doran (later Rehovot) from Yehoshua Hankin while still in Russia. He emigrated to Palestine in the early 1890s, where his first three children were born.
Destination: Palestine
→ Australia: 1 January 1901 (Fremantle)
He was the first of the family to arrive in Western Australia, coming with Sarah and their children. Hyam worked as a fruiterer and helped establish subsequent family members in Perth.
Read Hyam’s full biography →
3. Avraham Hochman (b. circa 1872)
Little is known about Avraham. He may have perished in Russia or emigrated without leaving records.
4. Josef Hochman (b. circa 1875)
Josef married Tubb’l and had children. His daughter Devora (Elka Dora) arrived in Melbourne in the 1920s, reporting that the remnant of the family still in Russia had been killed during the terrible pogroms of 1919.
5. Kolman Hochman (b. circa 1878)
Very little information is available about Kolman. He may have perished in Russia or emigrated without leaving records.
6. Binyamin Hochman (b. circa 1880)
Binyamin may have died young. His name was later given to a nephew, Ben Benzion Hoffman, son of Hershl, following Ashkenazi naming tradition.
7. Sholem Hochman (b. 1884, d. 1921)
Sholem married Shaindl Schutte. He may have emigrated to the United States (Pittsburgh is mentioned in family records).
Destination: The USA
8. Moshe משה Hoffman (b. 15 April 1884, d. 7 April 1973)
Born in Savran, Moshe (Moishe) trained as a wheelwright. He was conscripted into the Tsarist army around 1906 and served as a military wheelwright. He witnessed horrific pogroms, including mounted Cossacks decapitating Jews with swords.
→ Australia: 25 April 1910 (Fremantle, aboard the Scharnhorst)
Moshe arrived with Tobl and his 17-year-old nephew Wolfe. He became a successful fruiterer, publican, and businessman in Perth, establishing the family’s reputation in Western Australia.
Read Moshe’s full biography →
9. “Bobka” Hochman (b. circa 1885, d. during pogrom)
The only daughter among ten children. “Bobka” was likely a nickname derived from the Yiddish word for “beans,” also used to denote something small—perhaps “our kid sister.” She met her death in the river during a pogrom in Savran.
10. Yisrael Hochman (b. 1889, d. 1958)
The youngest son, known as Israel or Jack. He married Rachel Zelzer.
→ Australia: 1907
Yisrael arrived in Western Australia in 1907, joining his brother Hyam Yudl in the fruit trade and hospitality business.
The Next Generation: Berl, Hershl and Wolfe
Though technically the next generation, Berl and Hershl—the sons of Shimon Meir—were born in Savran and were roughly the same age as some of their younger uncles. They experienced the same harsh conditions and persecution, and they too became founding members of the Australian family.
11. Berl Hochman (b. circa 1885 in Savran, d. 1950)
Born in Savran before his family fled to Palestine. Berl grew up in harsh conditions and decided to seek his fortune in Australia.
→ Australia: 1904 (via Palestine)
Berl became a successful fruiterer in Westonia and other goldfield towns. In 1908, his bride Rivka Sisselman was sent from Palestine to marry him. They had four children, all born in Western Australia.
12. Hershl Hochman (b. 8 February 1888 in Savran, d. 11 December 1969)
Hershl (Harry or Hershel) was the second son of Shimon Meir, carried as an infant during the family’s desperate flight from Savran. He married Rachel Gillik from Chornomyn on 18 April 1908 in Jaffa. Hershl worked as a fitter and turner for an engineering company in Palestine.
→ Australia: 28 May 1915 (aboard the Orient Line’s Orsova)
Facing deteriorating conditions during World War I, Hershl and Rachel came to Australia with their two young sons, Bruce (age 6) and Ben (age 3). They paid £57 for their passage from Port Said. Four more children were born in Perth.
Hershl worked at Eilbeck’s Engineering Works in West Perth for 46 years, eventually becoming foreman. He was a respected member of the community and helped other Jewish immigrants establish themselves.
Read Hershl’s full biography →
13. Wolfe Hoffman (b. 1 November 1891 in Khoshchevato, Podolia)
Wolfe was the son of Josef Hochman. He left Russia together with his uncle Moshe when he was 17 years old.
→ Australia: 25 April 1910 (Fremantle, aboard the Scharnhorst)
Wolfe arrived with Moshe and worked as a labourer and millhand in Western Australia. He was naturalized in 1913.
World War I Service:
Wolfe enlisted in the Australian Imperial Force (AIF) on 20 March 1915 as Private 2224. He served with the 16th Battalion and arrived at Gallipoli in time for the Battle of Sari Bair (6-8 August 1915). He was a true “Digger”—the Australian term for ANZAC soldiers who served with courage and mateship during the Great War.
Read Wolfe’s full biography →
Why They Left: The Dark Years
From 1881 onward, the lives of Russia’s Jews were shattered by a relentless series of pogroms, restrictive laws, and state-sponsored violence.
Following the assassination of Tsar Alexander II in 1881, a wave of pogroms swept through southwestern Russia. In May 1882, Alexander III approved the infamous May Laws, temporarily forbidding Jews from settling outside towns, denying them mortgages, forbidding them from conducting business on Sundays and Christian holy days, imposing quotas on Jewish students in schools and universities, and barring Jews from many professions.
Between 1882 and 1921, the communities of Podolia—Savran, Bershad, and others—bore the brunt of massacres carried out by Tsarist forces, armed militias, Cossacks, and later revolutionary factions.
Moshe himself witnessed mounted troops with swords decapitating Jews in the streets.
By 1920, more than two million Jews had fled the Russian Empire. The vast majority went to the United States; others went to England, South Africa, Argentina, and Australia. About thirty thousand—the idealists and pioneers of the First and Second Aliyah—went to Ottoman Palestine to rebuild the Land of Zion.

pages/hoffman_history.title: hoffman_history
pages/hoffman_history.content:
The Hoffman history in Australia
Our family history in Australia begins in February 1901 when Haim Yudl and his family landed at the port of Fremantle.
After an introduction, I elaborate the histories as I have interpreted them. The first chapter of these histories deal with his earliest years in Australia, and the arrivals and histories of his brothers and nephews in Western Australia. Their stories are intimately related, as a dominant theme is the assistance and partnerships of one and the other in the new country. As such, in “The First Twenty Years” all their stories intertwined. After about 1920, all were independently employed or private businessmen, and each has his own chapter.
click here:
Haim Yudl and the Hoffmans - “The first twenty years”

pages/preface.title: Preface
pages/preface.content:
Preface by Peter Hoffman
As a child I had no greater interest in family history and genealogy than others of my age, however, I listened to my parents’ conversations, and without effort learned - and apparently faithfully memorised - little by little, a mass of data. Both my parents were in touch with and/or visited a large number of relatives both in Australia and overseas, and quite a few used to drop in at all hours to while away their time. So I overheard quite a lot. My grandfather Morrie Hoffman told us a few stories, but to my everlasting regret I never interrogated him with intent. In my teens I saw a genealogy of the Hoffman family which my father prepared for a relative in Melbourne, another Hymie Hoffman. A few years later I came across a brief outline of my grandmother Theresia’s ancestors, which she had written in the 1950’s. It so interested me that I copied it, and fortunately I kept my copy, because the original has been lost. It is clear that my interest to know more about my family was already kindled.
Later I saw and preserved genealogies prepared by my mother Edith, my aunt Val Hoffman, and more recently my father’s cousin Norm Hoffman, and my second cousin Philip Dzenciol, and others. Yet another genealogy was prepared in the 1970’s when a relative developed Hodgkin’s leukaemia, and a marrow donor had to be found.
In recent years I have made an effort to collect biographical material, however the sources whom I now know held the answers - our forebears - are long deceased. With regard to my grandparents, I woke up to this too late. It is a fact that whatever one doesn’t commit to paper in his lifetime will be lost forever. In fact, a paper record has become more durable than a digital record which is subject to the whims of the managers of the site. For that reason I now make every effort to avoid that error, and record relevant material and trivia alike. It is through the trivia that a person’s character will be appreciated.
With regard to my mother Edith’s family, as a child I knew that she was born in Vienna, that her father came from Nikolsburg NB, and at some earlier time his ancestor came from Switzerland, and that the name Spielmann meant troubadour. About her mother I knew that she came from Neunkirchen. Furthermore I knew that her mother’s family, Hönigsberg, was from Mattersdorf MD.
Over the years these sparse details became clearer to me. I found that most of my cousins knew no more.
At that time Nikolsburg and Mattersdorf were for me no more than names. In fact the connection with Mattersdorf was but a legend. My mother never visited there, though I understood that her mother did occasionally. My mother used to say that her cooking, which she had learnt from her own mother, was Hungarian. But that was no more than a hint, a taste of things which I would discover.
My knowledge of our origins has grown by degrees, by inquiry and by chance discovery of documents; by reason and by unexpected insights and correlations. Fortunately, the two Jewish communities – of Nikolsburg and of Mattersdorf– are among the best documented of the thousands destroyed by our persecutors. There are several developments which have immeasurably aided me in this ongoing work.
For one, the development of the Internet, which has enabled like-minded individuals to locate one another, share information, and meld into a community of researchers. Likewise it has been invaluable in locating and reestablishing contact with family members in various countries.
24.5.2024

pages/the_names.title: the_names
pages/the_names.content:
The Names Opus
The study of names - onomastics, is fascinating. The origins and meanings of some of my family names eluded me for years. But one by one, and by various strokes of fortune, I arrived at the answers. Here I put them on record, both for their intrinsic interest, and to spare any other soul the effort I made to reach my conclusions. Names based on physiognomy and personal traits, Biblical figures, given names of relatives, occupations, places of origin, etc, are typical of those chosen by Jews. Throughout Europe, at various times civil administrations legislated that Jews adopt family names, whereas previously they had only given names and patronyms.
Hochman Goichman Hoffman Hoffmann
Hochman simply is a tall man. Hoch הוך is Yiddish for high. The Yiddish spelling is הוכמאן. The family lived in Podolia, Poland which was annexed by Russia in 1793. The Russian administration, lacking the consonant “h” in speech and in script, substituted a Cyrillic “g” , hence the name was written and pronounced as Goichman.
When the family migrated to Australian and the USA, the locals were unable to pronounce the gutteral “ch” sound. About 1904, Haym Yudl Hochman began to write his name as Hoffman, and
subsequently, other newly arriving family members did the same, and changed their name to Hoffman. As an illustration of how arbitrary names were, at one time Hyam himself used the name “Hiram” in his dealings as fruit and wine seller retailer.
There is one instance of the Hoffmann variant. My grandparents bought tickets to Australia on a German ship, the Scharnhorst, in Port Said in 1910. The shipping agent registered them as Hoffmann, a quite acceptable German name, and as such they landed at Fremantle.
Alzofen
This was my great grandmother’s maiden name in Poldolia. It is a rare name borne by Jews in several countries. Yiddish speaking Jews would pronounce the Hebrew given name El-tzafan (or Elitzafan) as Al-zo-fen, with the accent on the second syllable. Eltzafan אליצפן the son of Uzi’el of the tribe of Levi, was a cousin of Moses. See parashat Shmini, Leviticus.
Sisselman
My grandfather’s eldest brother Shimon Me’ir took his second wife Frida from this family. His son Berl married Frida’s sister Rivka. Thus many of the Hoffman family are descended from the Sisselmans. The origin of the name is explained in the autobiography and genealogy of Rabbi Ya’akov Zvi Sisselman, their father. His ancestor, who lived near the city of Pinsk married a women called Zissel. Ziss, in Yiddish (as in German) means sweet. He became known as Zissel’s man.

pages/zitserman.title: zitserman
pages/zitserman.content:
This paper includes updates as of October 2024.
   This uncommon Jewish family name was my grandmother’s maiden name.     I have not found its origin  in any source, however  I learned that in Yiddish
a person who sits on a panel or in  judgment  is a besitser בעזיצער   from the word  “zits”  זיץ  to sit.  Thus a zitserman   זיצערמאן   or as it is sometimes
written –  zaitserman -  must have  been a dayan   דיין  
 a member of a rabbinical court.  In European languages constructions using the root words for  seats, sitting (and even thronus) such as chairman, assizes,
seat of goverment, a sitting, etc, are common.  
   Aaron Zitserman of Bershad married  Elka Vestil.
    A digression into these names:
I have the name Vestil  from the death certificates of two of his daughters  (Tob’l and Pessy)  where it is their mother’s family name.
The death certificate of Mariam notes that her mother was named Elka.
This we know to be true. It follows that Vestil can only be the family name.
Each of the three daughters – Tob’l, Pessy and Mariam - bore  a  daughter
named Elke – they were Alyce Hoffman, Olga Schwarz and Elke Greenberg
– in line with Jewish naming conventions. On his daughters’  death certificates Aaron was described as a business proprietor.
   Vestil: This rare Jewish family name appears to be unique to Russia and Moldavia. A search of the Jewish Genealogy databases and of the Shoah victims listed by Yad Vashem has not turned up much of relevance. Vestil is a diminutive of vest, and as such refers to the fringed undershirt worn by  ארנע ארבעה כנפות  religious Jewish men: ie: arba kanfot.
  Their six children, were born in Bershad.
    1.  Arkadia.  She remained in Russia. She was married to a Zitserman (sic)  and had a daughter named Galya.
              We have no more details of this family.
    2.  Frida  ~1887 – 1955.  d.  in Odessa.
                Frida married  Mocha  Pesach of Olgopol.
               Olgopol was a town near Vinnitsa in the Podolia oblast.
               After about 1941 Olgopol became part of Transnistria, and was  no
              longer in the Ukraine or the USSR.
               They had six children of whom three (a.  c.  d.)  were war widows.
              a.  Charna.  Came out from Odessa as an old lady to Israel
                   and d. in Israel.
                   I know nothing of her. She had no issue.
                    She married (given name not known) Pesach.                                                                           
                     He was conscripted and fell in the world war.
               b.  Manya  May.  d.  in Odessa.  She married Boris Granovski.
                   He was a lieutenant, who fell at Stalingrad in 1942.
                   Their daughter was Nelli Granovski, b. 1935.  d. in Israel  ~2010.
                   Nelli suffered from a hereditary neural dystrophy (Charcot Marie
                   Tooth) which affected her legs.
                   Nelli’s son Leonid b. ~1970 lives in Israel.
                    He has inherited the neural dystrophy from his mother.
                    He is single and has no issue.  I can’t tap him for more information
                    as he prefers not to respond.
              c.  Fanya  Feiga.  d. in Israel.    She married Pesach Zvesdina.
                   Came out from Odessa as an old lady to Israel and d. in Israel.
                   I know nothing of her. She had no issue.
              d.  Bronya  Bracha  b.  ~1918 in Olgopol.  d. Israel
                     Came out from Odessa as an old lady to Israel
                     and d. in Israel.
                     Bronya  m. Michael Solgan, b. in Olgopol. 
                     Michael was a captain (4 pips) in the  Red Army.
                     He fell in 1942  (before the battle of Stalingrad).
                     Their son Yefim (Fima) was born in 1938. He was a civil engineer
                     whose interest was in hydraulics.
                      He left Odessa and came to Israel. He had his own taxi and
                     supported himself until it was stolen.  After that he emigrated to                
                       Perth.  We were on very good terms. When I was in Perth                           
                     about ten years ago he was not at home. I don’t know the
                     situation  today.
                      Fima has a son, b. ~1970  in Russia, who remains there, he studied
                       turbines at the technical college in  St. Petersburg.
                e.  Arkadi  Aaron  Pesach b. ~1917. He was  a colonel (polkovnik)
                       in the Red Army who  fought  as far as Berlin. In later life he lived
                       in St. Petersburg. I know nothing more.
                f.   Yaakov (Yankele) Pesach  b.~1925,
                       killed in action, aet. 17 years in 1943.
    In 1928, my grandfather Morris  Hoffman nominated  Frida and Leib and their six children for immigration  to Australia  (Australian National Archives, item 8183056). This did not eventuate. This was in the time of the antisemitic
repressive USSR.
 3.  Tobl          ~1890 – 1958   (our grandmother)  in 1909 married Moshe 
                      Hochman  of Savran. They went to Perth in 1910.
                     Their six children were:
                      Aaron (Harry)      6.1.1912 - 1973                    
                      Beile                     1915-1917
                      Hymen Juda        28.4.1918 – 17.7.2007,
                           married Edith Spielmann 1918-2008.
                            Their children are:
                               Edward Denis   b. 27.12.1944.   d. 2017.
                               Peter                    b. 28.11.1946.
                               Dianne Helen      b. 6.9.1948.
                      Wolfe               b. 1920   d. 2001.
                      Elke (Alyce)     b. 6.4.1923   d.2.3.2013  
                      Yaakov (Jack)   b. 18.5.1927  d. 4.7.2019 in Perth.
4.  Pesia (Batya)   b. 28.4.1893 in Bershad   d. 30.7.1959  in Perth.
       In 1916 married Pinya Swartz  b. 10.6.1889  in Russia, d. 3.7.1932  in Perth.
         He was a Pinchas, and both Philip Dzienciol and I (Peter Hoffman)
          were named for him. His father was Moshe, whose sobriquet was “Moishe der lange”
             i.e. the tall.  His mother was Leika (Leah).
                Their children were:
           Olga  Elka  25.4.1918 - 3.12.1995,   who married Sydney  Breckler.
                     Olga and Syd had a son Paul , who brought his                                                 
                     penpal Gloria from the Philipines to Perth and married her.
            Leah Leika  27.3.1920 – 23.7.2000,   who married Morry Dzienciol.
                 Their children are:
                     Philip  b.  8.8.1942
                     Simon  b. 3.9.1945
                     Bray   b. 10.10.1949
                            These three sons have children and grandchildren in Australia.
           Rachel  b. 26.7.1922.   Rachel married Jan.
                    They had no children.
           May  Manya  b. 18.12.1924,  who married Ray Adam.
                    They had two sons.
           Morris  Moshe  b. 26.9.1926  in Perth.   He married Mollie.
                     They had no children.
           Harry  Aaron  21.12.1930 – 22.6.1994.  b. & d. in Perth.
       On the 10.10.1925 on the vessel Ville de Verdun (Messageries Maritimes),
   Pesia and Pinya and the four eldest children arrived at Fremantle
 5.  Mariam   1907-3.9.1972     married Motti Millman in Russia. 
        Motti died in a tram accident in Odessa.
           Their two daughters were:
             Sarah  (Sally) b. 1926 in Russia.
                     She married   Max Crain.
               They had three children:  Myron, Jenny and Paul who live in the USA.
         Mariam and the girls came to Perth ~1932.  She married again,
          to Moshe Greenberg  in 1932. Morris was aged 25. Both are deceased.
               And   Elka   b. 1932 in Russia.
               She married Michael Kemeny. They lived in Nedlands and owned and
           managed a general store. Elka passed away in .
           Michael passed away in 2024 at the age of 98.
 
Letter from Myron Crain.  M & M Crain mandmcrain@yahoo.com
Sent: July 03, 2020 2:16 PM
To: Sandi Kerr
Cc: hh_peter@yahoo.com ; rebealimelekh@hotmail.com
Myron turned up on my sister’s DNA. This is his cordial letter to us from 2020.
Dear Sandi, Peter and David,
    Thanks so much for taking some time to write to me.  The Hoffmans were always some news from my mother Sara as we were growing up and throughout her life.  I have vague recollections of being with some of you when my family lived in Perth for six months in 1955.  I think that I attended some sort of religious school on occasion or other event.
    Anyway, my wife Margie and I live on the island of Kauai in Hawaii.  We retired here from San Diego 11 years ago.  We never had children by choice.  We will be married 50 years this September. My sister Jenny and her husband Shelly Silver live in Cape Cod, Massachusetts and have a 31 year old son, Sam who usually lives in Brooklyn, N.Y. with his long time partner Allison.  They are staying with Jenny and Shelly while the pandemic settles down (if ever).  Jenny lived in Perth only for about six months or so with my parents in 1973 and not since. My brother Paul is long divorced and lives in Carlsbad, California.  He never had children either.  Our family tree is much simpler than yours! All three of us are retired now.
    We usually travel a great deal for pleasure but are stationary at his point in time, as you might suspect.  Being stuck on Kauai isn’t so bad and we are enjoying it.   I went to UCLA and California State for my bachelors degree and then to USC for an MBA.  I spent my working years in Real Estate and construction always working for myself. We lived in Southern and Central California all of our working years.
    My only living relative on Sara’s side is Michael Kemeny, Alka’s (Alice’s) husband, who is 94 and living at Montgomery House care facility in Mont Claremont, Perth.  Paul, Jenny and myself have visited him many times over the years, most recently last year.
    Please forward this on as you please.
All the very best, Myron
   I was born Sept. 20, 1946.
     In 1927, my grandfather Morris  Hoffman nominated  Motchka Millman, Marian and their children for immigration  to Australia  (Australian National Archives).
 6   Yaakov  (Yankele)   birth order not known.   Leah Dzienciol  said that he
         was a dayan in Bershad.
           Yaakov’s great grandson Alex Igoudin “found” us in August 2017,
       and  he has united our families and given us the following family details:
           Yankel Zitserman was probably born in the 1880s.
       He married Rachel (no last name survives). Yakov died sometime between
       1913 and 1916.  Yakov might have enlisted in the Russian army during   
       WWI, in which Russia participated from 1914 to 1917, and perished then.
       They had two children:
           Maryam Zitserman (1913)
        Maryam would have been only 1-2 years old when her father died.
          and  Aaron Zitserman, birth year is not listed. He went to Argentina in
       the 1930s, returned to Ukraine, enlisted when the war broke out, and
       was killed at the front in 1941. He never married, and  had no children.
    We know of a Zitserman family, that left Russia and came to Sydney
  in 1980.  Ruth Glasser Hoffman, by chance, met them.
  In August 1997  Philip Dzienciol  visited and interviewed them with the
  intention of learning their family history.
    They are descended from
         Yoel (Yankele) Zitserman of Bershad,  and Gittel.
   Philip concluded that Yoel and our great grandfather Aaron  were  brothers.
   This has been subsequently confirmed by Lane**.**
      Philip also thought that Gittel  and  our great grandmother Elke
   were sisters.
        Yoel and Gittel had four sons and two daughters:
           Yitzchak
           Mordechai
           Shaike
           Moishe
           Batya
         and Chaiya.
     Shaike  b. ~ 1883,   d. ~ 1932.  a furrier,  married Raizel Fabrikant of Bershad.
    Shaike’s son was Luser (Eliezer)  b. 1921 in Bershad.  He married Ruchel Rya
     who  came with him to Sydney.
         Luser, the pater familias,  was Philip’s informant.
       Luser’s sibs were:
                   Mottl    b. 1910,    killed in the Second World War.                
                   Yoel   d. ~1987 in Kharkov.
                   Soybel  (a daughter).    dec.
                   Shaike,  a son    lived in Philadelphia, USA.
                   Ruchel,                lived in Philadelphia, USA.
               and Esther.     d. ~1991
         Luser married Rachel.
           Their son Mark (Marik) b. 1953 in Kharkov,  married Ella.
            They live in Sydney.
               Their children are Allanah and Deborah (Debbie)
            Their daughter Inna  b. 1958 in Kharkov,  an accountant,
              married Adolf (Eddy) Krimotat.
            They have has two children:
             Michael  b. 1981 in Sydney
           and  Jonathan  b. 1983 in Sydney.
         Read about Allanah:
     Allanah Zitserman - Wikipedia
      en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allanah_Zitserman
      Allanah Zitserman arrived in Australia in 1980 with her family,
        as a Russian refugee……..
       Allanah married Stavros Kazantzidis , her collaborator.  They live in Dungog  NSW.
       Their elder  daughter,  Mila, b. ~ 2011.
       Their younger, Lula Ophelia,  b. 7.3.2013.
=============================================================================   
  Other Zitsermans from Bershad
        – we have no proof of kinship with us.
Tatiana Zitserman   b. in Bershad.  Chess master.  Now lives in Minnesota.
  Was a member of the US national team.
Boris Mikhailovich Ziсerman  b. 1960 in Bershad
 Also known as  Efim Alexandrov - Wikipedia
 Efim Alexandrov Russian artist of “spoken word” genre (stand-up comedian) and well known … Lubov Efimovna and Boris Mikhailovich Ziсerman  were born in the township of Bershad
www.languagesoftheworld.info/…/re-branding-soviet-jewish-nostalgia-jewis…
=========================================================================
